channel.title: BBC News - World

item.title: Kabul airport attack: What do we know?
item.description: The bombings came hours after warnings to citizens to stay away from the airport, due to an imminent threat.

item.title: US judge reprimands Trump election fraud lawyers
item.description: A US district judge accuses Sidney Powell and others of trying to undermine faith in democracy.

item.title: Trial suggests malaria sickness could be cut by 70%
item.description: Seasonal vaccines and drugs could save millions of young lives in Africa, researchers say.

item.title: Israel's Bennett seeks reset with US at first meeting with Biden
item.description: Israeli PM hopes Joe Biden will agree to help stop Iran's nuclear programme at their first meeting.

item.title: Stalin-era mass grave found in Ukraine
item.description: Thousands of people are thought to be buried at the site - one of the largest ever found in Ukraine.

item.title: New species of ancient four-legged whale discovered in Egypt
item.description: The three-metre whale was found in Egypt and has been named after Anubis, the ancient god of death.

item.title: Nah he tweakin: What it means and why it's all over our timelines
item.description: A row on the use of blood in celebrity-endorsed products has made those three words viral.

item.title: Ron Jeremy: US adult film star indicted on 34 sex crime charges
item.description: Ron Jeremy has pleaded not guilty to assault allegations from 21 women that span over two decades.

item.title: Abba: Band teases major announcement ahead of new music
item.description: The band, who have not released new music for 39 years, reveal a new project called Abba Voyage.

item.title: Venezuela searches for landslide survivors as more rains fall
item.description: Twenty people are confirmed to have died after heavy rains caused landslides in western Venezuela.

item.title: Australian farmer draws heart with sheep in tribute to aunt
item.description: The Australian man was unable to attend his aunt's funeral because of Covid travel restrictions.

item.title: Young Afghan mayor who fled Taliban hidden in car
item.description: One of Afghanistan's first female mayors, Zarifa Ghafari, describes her dramatic escape to Germany.

item.title: Afghanistan crisis: Who are Isis-K?
item.description: The jihadist group - set up in 2015 - is blamed for some of the worst atrocities in recent years.

item.title: The real victims of mass crypto-hacks that keep happening
item.description: Millions in Bitcoin and other digital coins are being stolen by hackers with victims left in limbo.

item.title: Why rent control isnâ€™t working in Sweden
item.description: Young people are struggling to afford city living, and even the Swedes can't crack the problem.

item.title: The hard men removing squatters in Spain
item.description: Some squatters in Spain demand cash before leaving - so eviction firms have arisen to handle the talks.

item.title: Kenya's Deputy President Ruto campaigns for 'Hustler Nation'
item.description: Deputy President William Ruto is portraying himself as the champion of the poor ahead of elections.

item.title: Madagascar on the brink of climate change-induced famine
item.description: The country is on the brink of experiencing the world's first "climate change famine", the UN says.

item.title: Charlie Watts: The subtle magnificence of the Rolling Stones' drummer
item.description: He wasn't flashy or prone to pyrotechnics, but Charlie Watts was the heartbeat of the Rolling Stones.

item.title: Kabul airport bomb attack leaves many casualties
item.description: US officials also say there were reports of gunfire following the blast.

item.title: Afghanistan: Former Royal Marine on the chaos at Kabul airport
item.description: A former Royal Marine, who was near to the explosions at Kabul airport, describes being caught in the chaos.

item.title: Afghanistan: 'The pain of watching my country burn from afar'
item.description: Hundreds of Afghan have taken refuge in India but they are worried about their families back home.

item.title: Tears on the tarmac as Afghan journalist speaks to BBC
item.description: Wahida Faizi says she cannot stay in Afghanistan because she believes the Taliban will kill her.

item.title: Mass brawl erupts in Armenian parliament: Third violent bout in just two days
item.description: Security personnel were called in to remove several members after violence erupted on the parliament floor.

item.title: Afghanistan: The 'undefeated' Panjshir Valley - an hour from Kabul
item.description: The Panjshir Valley has been a flashpoint in Afghanistan's turbulent history - now it's happening again.

item.title: Bilal Sarwary: 'The plane hit the tower and all our lives changed'
item.description: Afghan journalist Bilal Sarwary was selling carpets when 9/11 happened. From that day on, everything changed.

item.title: Afghanistan: How much opium is produced and what's the Taliban's record?
item.description: The Taliban claims opium poppy cultivation was stopped when it last held power in Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghanistan chaos: The British families in limbo
item.description: The stories of Britons stuck in Kabul, families in limbo and Afghans starting new lives in the UK.

item.title: A Kabul evacuee's tale: Dread, chaos and the Taliban
item.description: An Indian woman tells the BBC of the on-and-off trauma of getting out of Taliban-held Afghanistan.

item.title: Business still has time to help Afghans - AirBnB boss
item.description: Co-founder Brian Chesky urges more firms to help after promising free lodging for 20,000 refugees.
